climbs.name: Alien Sex Fiends
climbs.fa: Dean Hart, Bruce McDonald, Kevin McLane

content.description:
Crux above the 4th bolt. Good mantling. A little mossy in just a couple spots. Some crystals for foot holds and interesting sequences.



Directly above the anchor on Mosquito. Left of Plegmish Dance.

Bolts. Chains on top.

A short pitch on its own, but of significantly more merit if continues as a direct finish to SM's Delight.  The rock appears broken and rough, but the holds and protection are good. 
 The pitch is best done as an extension to the single pitch of SM's delight, as it lies directly in line with that climb and is consistent with most of it's climbing. 

From the bolt and chain anchor atop SM's delight, this climb is the threaded cracks  leaning slightly left, directly overhead.
A few small cams and stoppers protect this climb, and get you to a 2-bolt anchor (no chains to rap from) up and left, high on the slab above. To retreat without walking Rap or lower in 2 stages as for the anchors on Mosquito back down to the anchors for  Mosquito or SM's Delight and re-thread.  Even a single 70M won't quite get you down to the base of the lower wall from the top of this.

This is the notch between "Sex" and "Rock 'n' Roll"

Guidebook says SR to 2" (I haven't climbed it)

A worthwhile crack if you are stumped by the Jabberwocky boulder problem, or already done it. A alterate start to Jabberwocky. left of Jabberwocky.
there is a bolted anchor, same as Jabberwocky. standard rack, long slings for traversing and wandering back and forth.

A bouldery low crux leads to a nice technical finger crack.

The route starts on the upper tier of the smoke bluff wall.
Standard rack to 3/4 in.

Steep and dynamic

Right of Zombie Roof, Left of Old Age
4 bolts

Another great hand and finger crack.  Plenty of protection.

From the Zombie Roof (mondo roof with a crack running through it, visible from the trail), follow a trail along the base of the wall to the left. It switches back up, under a large boulder, to a fixed hand-line. Climb the hand-line (not trivial, some may want a belay) up to the ledge. Toward the right end of the ledge begins Laughing Crack (it will be obvious). Rappel the route.
Gear to 2 inches.  Two-bolt anchor on top.

This is the start for the "Smoke Bluff Connection".

Handjam and lieback to a good ledge.

The hardest "5.8" in the bluffs and maybe the best one, too.
content.location: It's the most obvious line at this crag.

climbs.name: No-see-um
climbs.fa: S. Frimer, B. Backhouse, J. Frimer

content.description:
Up a corner immediately right of Mosquito past a block (crux), then wriggle up a deep corner/chimney.

immediately right of Mosquito
standard rack

climbs.name: Old Age
climbs.fa: Bob Milward, Peter Shackleton, Robin Barley: April 1984

content.description:
Old Age climbs a fun corner with some interesting moves up steep rock about halfway up.  Good rests are available before the harder sections.

This route starts on the right side of the Zombie Roof in a large left facing dihedral.  Rap the route or lower off with one 60m rope.
A single set of wires and cams to a #3 Camalot.  There is a two bolt anchor at the top.

From the top of Mosquito, step slightly right, then continue up thin, parallel cracks to the top.  Consistent, interesting 5.8 finger jams and stemming the whole way.

To descend: Continue up Smoke Bluff Connection to the top, or 2 rappells to the base of Mosquito.
Gear to 2", emphasize wires and small cams. The gear is great to the top, but every placement looks like it will be your last.

climbs.name: Rock and Roll
climbs.fa: 1985 I. Christiansen.  Recleaned 2010 by J. Frimer

content.description:
In 2010, this route was reclaimed from the jungle.  The opening left facing corner is technical and fun.  Head up and then a little right and pass through the gap to the left of the capstone.

Right of Mosquito, find the largest left facing open book. It starts directly off a little platform.
Standard rack to #3 camalot.

A great, technical seam up a steep headwall is the highlight of this little gem.

The seam splitting the headwall is obvious. Climb the easy corner below to access it.
RPs/HP offsets (bring a few of the medium to bigger sizes) to #2 camalot. Gear is excellent despite appearances.  Rap anchors on top.

A great new pitch! Technical steep shallow corner to start, and then clip the two bolts on the arete leading to the capstone.  Head up to the capstone (steep) and then move right and layback to the top.

The last appealing corner/slot to the right of Mosquito. You can see the two bolts on the arete above the corner.  The bolts are on arete to the LEFT of this corner.  There is another corner shallow between this and Rock & Roll to the left.
Standard rack - bring a #4 or #4.5 camalot for the top.

Climb the slightly flared crack just left of Mosquito. Thin gear and technical feet to start before a deceptive crux. Get into good hands up an easing and widening crack to an optional belay. If continuing up Phlegmish Dance, step right across the slab to the second anchor on the bigger ledge.

Small rack to 3" - emphasis in .4-.75

The most popular link up at the Smoke Bluffs, and with good reason.  A case of the sum being greater than its parts. 
  
 Climb Mosquito (5.8), then Phlegmish Dance (5.8).  Walk ~50 feet through the woods and climb Jabberwocky (5.10b).  Finish with Wonderland (5.9).  Smile.

Start as for Mosquito.  Walk off from the top of Wonderland.
Gear to 3".  Bolted anchors on each pitch.

Long, left-leaning hand-crack visible from the main trail directly below wonderland. Start by romping up flakes and then pulling up cracks in a corner. Traverse out to the splitter 40' thin-to-wide hands crack. Great intro to the size. There is an extension above the anchor which leads into Wonderland at 5.10b (Sparky Goes to Wonderland).

Approach as for Jabberwocky by way of the smoke bluff connection or by wandering down from Pixie Corner. Start on bulges and flakes 10' left of Jabberwocky.
Standard rack to 3". Doubles in 1-2" are useful, as are some extendable draws. Bolts and chains at the top.

Just right of Mosquito is a boulder that once surmounted leads to this very fun face.

A couple of medium cams (1/2 to 1 inch) and long slings are necessary, but it's mostly bolted.

The legendary roof crack in the Smoke Bluffs. Start up an easy groove tp get established on a good jug at the start of the roof. Then use hand-jams, fingerlocks, heel-toe cams and more crack trickery to climb through the roof with a cruxy sequence just before turning the lip. Better than it looks!

Just off the trail before 'Mosquito' very easy to find.
Gear to 2 inches...

This cliff provides some of the longest and best routes, which makes this one of the most popular areas to climb.  It also has a variety of links ups which provide fun multi pitch climbing.  
  
 New routes have been cleaned and added to the right of Mosquito.  Check of this site (2010) for a topo: 
  
  jeremyfrimer.com/Climbing_Râ€¦
